title: Authors and Citation
Authors and Citation
text: Last F (2025). nicknames: Package (One Line, Title Case). R package version 0.0.0.9000, http://simson.io/nicknames/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {nicknames: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)},   author = {First Last},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {http://simson.io/nicknames/}, }

what: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Nicknames allows specify human readable names columns data reuse across project rename plots axes, dataframe columns, tables anything else.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: can install development version nicknames GitHub :

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: nicknames, can register mapping columns data human readable column names easily re-use everywhere. Including ggplot2 plots…  …dataframes… …column names directly. variables names extracted within function calls (e.g. factor(cyl) ), exact matches take priority need precise.
code:
library(nicknames)  nn_register(c(   "mpg" = "Miles per Gallon",   "hp" = "Horsepower",   "cyl" = "Number of
Cylinders" )) library(ggplot2)  # Create plot and apply nickname labels ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = hp, color = factor(cyl))) +   geom_point() +   labs_nn() library(dplyr)  mtcars |>   select(mpg, hp, cyl) |>   nn() |>   head() #>                   Miles per Gallon Horsepower Number of
Cylinders #> Mazda RX4                     21.0        110                    6 #> Mazda RX4 Wag                 21.0        110                    6 #> Datsun 710                    22.8         93                    4 #> Hornet 4 Drive                21.4        110                    6 #> Hornet Sportabout             18.7        175                    8 #> Valiant                       18.1        105                    6 nn("mpg") #> [1] "Miles per Gallon" nn_register(c(   "factor(cyl)" = "Number of
Cylinders (factor)" ))  ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = hp, color = factor(cyl))) +   geom_point() +   labs_nn()

what: Map Names to Aesthetic Labels in ggplot2 — labs_map
title: Map Names to Aesthetic Labels in ggplot2 — labs_map
text: function automatically maps variable names labels based plot's aesthetic mapping. provides convenient way set multiple labels matching names provided aes / used default ggplot prespecified list.

title: Map Names to Aesthetic Labels in ggplot2 — labs_map
Map Names to Aesthetic Labels in ggplot2 — labs_map
text: names named list vector names variable names values desired labels variables plot.

title: Map Names to Aesthetic Labels in ggplot2 — labs_map
text: object class "labs_map" can added ggplot object using + operator. added, automatically apply appropriate labels based plot's aesthetic mappings.

title: Map Names to Aesthetic Labels in ggplot2 — labs_map
text: particularly useful consistent naming scheme variables want apply human-readable labels without manually specifying aesthetic.

title: Map Names to Aesthetic Labels in ggplot2 — labs_map
code:
library(ggplot2)  # Create plot and apply labels ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = hp, color = factor(cyl))) +   geom_point() +   labs_map(c(     "mpg" = "Miles per Gallon",     "hp" = "Horsepower",     "cyl" = "Number of
Cylinders"   ))   # Even though names (e.g. cyl) are extracted, exact matches take priority ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = hp, color = factor(cyl))) +   geom_point() +   labs_map(c(     "mpg" = "Miles per Gallon",     "hp" = "Horsepower",     "cyl" = "Number of
Cylinders",     "factor(cyl)" = "Number of
Cylinders (factor)"   ))

what: Use Nicknames in ggplot2 Plots — labs_nn
title: Use Nicknames in ggplot2 Plots — labs_nn
text: function provides convenient way apply human readable labels ggplot2 plots, first registering using nn_register applying using function.

title: Use Nicknames in ggplot2 Plots — labs_nn
Use Nicknames in ggplot2 Plots — labs_nn
text: dict dictionary name use nickname lookups (optional).

title: Use Nicknames in ggplot2 Plots — labs_nn
text: makes easy specify nice names use across project.

title: Use Nicknames in ggplot2 Plots — labs_nn
code: library(ggplot2)  # Register nicknames nn_register(c(   "mpg" = "Miles per Gallon",   "hp" = "Horsepower",   "factor(cyl)" = "Number of\nCylinders" ))  # Create plot and apply nickname labels ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = hp, color = factor(cyl))) +   geom_point() +   labs_nn()

what: Add Labels to Dataframe Columns via Nicknames — nn_add_labels
title: Add Labels to Dataframe Columns via Nicknames — nn_add_labels
text: function takes dataframe adds labels columns registered nicknames. labels stored "label" attribute matching column visible e.g. Rstudio data viewer.

title: Add Labels to Dataframe Columns via Nicknames — nn_add_labels
Add Labels to Dataframe Columns via Nicknames — nn_add_labels
text: df dataframe add labels dict dictionary name use nickname lookups (defaults "default")

title: Add Labels to Dataframe Columns via Nicknames — nn_add_labels
text: dataframe label attributes added matching columns

title: Add Labels to Dataframe Columns via Nicknames — nn_add_labels
code: # Register some nickname mappings nn_register(c(   "mpg" = "Miles per Gallon",   "hp" = "Horsepower",   "cyl" = "Number of Cylinders" ))  # Add labels to mtcars dataframe labeled_mtcars <- nn_add_labels(mtcars)  # If you're using Rstudio, run View(labeled_mtcars) # or check the labels manually: attr(labeled_mtcars$mpg, "label") # "Miles per Gallon" #> [1] "Miles per Gallon" attr(labeled_mtcars$hp, "label") # "Horsepower" #> [1] "Horsepower"

title: Nickname registration and lookup — nn_register
Nickname registration and lookup — nn_register
code: nn_register(mappings, dict = "default")  nn(x, dict = "default")  # Default S3 method nn(x, dict = "default")  # S3 method for class 'data.frame' nn(x, dict = "default")

title: Nickname registration and lookup — nn_register
text: mappings named vector names original values values nicknames dict dictionary name use (defaults "default"). x value look , can dataframe character vector.

title: Nickname registration and lookup — nn_register
text: nn_register() returns nothing. nn() returns nickname one registered, otherwise original value.

title: Nickname registration and lookup — nn_register
code: # Register some nickname mappings nn_register(c(   "Jennifer" = "Jen",   "Robert" = "Bob",   "Elizabeth" = "Liz" ))  # Look up nicknames nn("Jennifer")  # Returns "Jen" #> [1] "Jen" nn("Robert")    # Returns "Bob" #> [1] "Bob" nn("John")      # Returns "John" (no mapping registered) #> [1] "John"  # Use different dictionaries nn_register(c("Jennifer" = "Jenny"), dict = "alt") nn("Jennifer")              # Returns "Jen" (from default dict) #> [1] "Jen" nn("Jennifer", dict = "alt") # Returns "Jenny" (from alt dict) #> [1] "Jenny"
